description: Borrowed from New Latin laryngismus, from the Ancient Greek λαρυγγισμός (larungismós, “a croaking”), from λάρυγξ (lárunx), whence also larynx; surface analysis, laryng- +‎ -ismus.

entries.meaning: (medicine) A spasmodic state of the glottis, giving rise to contraction or closure of the opening; laryngospasm.
